body: OK, thanks.
Yes, we can remove that macro

I am guessing that the speedup of separate measuring comes from the cache warm-up in the packing steps. When measuring the packing separately, the data to-be-packed stays in the cache for repeated running. The data will be flushed out if the convolution takes place right after packing, i.e. measured together.
Now it was fixed by changing this line of code, and I created a PR
Thanks for reporting this. Can you help to change it to assign style(three line assignment) so it fits into c++11 standard?

I understand the need of introducing backward ptr to schedule, but this will potentially break the auto serialization of Schedule. TVM allows serialization of any Node object as long as all its field are node or types known to TVM.

Can we change the API a bit, e.g. at schedule level, or introduce a stage/schedule pair(returned by Schedule.operator []) to resolve this problem?
it is not necessary, consumer was a tag that do not bear any meaning, it is deleted in FlattenSeq so we can see through this scope.
See https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/include/tvm/ir.h#L259 there is a rw_mask, which gives you information about whether it is a write or store access
sure, my pleasure @tqchen
Great. I will work on the codegen, then. Should I report my progress somewhere?

without this patch n.extents[0].value is 80

I'm fine with changing the API as long as it somehow provides me the functionality I need. 
What I need to do is to be able to get from the Stage object (while in Stage::autotensorize() method) to the Schedule object so that I can normalize it, etc. In the solution you suggested, the pairs are stored at the schedule object, so we are back to the same problem. Or did you mean that we store all those pairs in a static data member in Schedule? Can you elaborate please?
Another solution I thought about was to pass the schedule as an argument on the Python side, e.g. s[C].autotensorize(C, intrin). Technically, C is redundant (there is only one valid argument value, i.e., C) so it's not a clean design. That's why I didn't use that solution. If anyone can think of a variation or if there is no way around this problem, I'll be ok using it.
Sorry I'll have to pause for ~ half a week. Being busy currently.
Did you install llvm successfully?

I think s.autotensorize(C, intrin) is a fine API, as the schedule primitive on s indicates it requires global information, while s[C] only requires local information

For the pair solution, without breaking the cyclic dependency:
  -  Schedule hold ONLY stage(no stage wrapper),
  -  Schedule.operator[] returns StageWrapper, which contains pair(schedule, stage), and implements the Stage functionalities.
Yes, I build it successfully after I select "release" instead of "debug". You can try it!

aaaargh! I had made a stupid mistake, had fixed my mind (and code) on defining autotensorize on Stage instead of Schedule. When I define autotensorize on Schedule (which makes more sense) I don't need a data structure to get from Stage object to Schedule object. Thanks for the clarification. I'll send my modified PR soon.
I also added the API and the outline of the implementation for autotensorize.
cc @yidawang
Thanks!

Tianqi,

1-bit looks a cool feature. However, in our internal experiments, 1-bit weight(with 4-bit activation) still has non-negligible accuracy degradation(the best result still has around 3 percentage gap). So may I ask why we want to invest resource on this low-bit feature? Internally we are also leveraging TVM for boosting our productivity and already submit small patch to the community. We would like to align our engineering efforts with the community. Model compression is right now on our radars, and we would like to leverage TVM for fully exploiting the potential of model compressions.

Thanks.

We want to keep doors open for different kinds of optimizations, low bits(not necessarily 1bit) is among one of them. We are also thinking about more general low-bits(e.g. 2, 3 or 4 bits) operations. they allow interesting tradeoffs to be made(not necessarily).This direction can also be of particular interest to folks who works on hardware optimizations.
rfactor might be related, @merrymercy might have some experience on related issues
8bit inference is the most important thing 😄

Comments on last commit: In TVM when we have a CHECK* macro, the program exits when a condition is not satisfied. When we call tensorize on a given loop, if that loop is not tensorizable with the given intrinsic one of these CHECK calls fail and we exit TVM. However, in autotensorization, we need to check all iteration variables, and when one of the checks fail for a given iteration variable, we need to go on to the next iteration variable (and not exit TVM). That's why I needed a new type of CHECK* macros (called COND_CHECK*) that can either quit, return false, or do anything else when their condition is false.
I'm not picky about the name of the new macros, or the name of the new variables, or anything else, as long as I get the functionality I need. So please let me know if you can think of a cleaner way of doing this.
There is a lint error that I don't know how to suppress or fix. That's why the build fails. Please see my comments in the last commit and let me know if you have a suggestion.

Ok just done some digging with this test - the one that was failing was the python one (not the c++ one) which was already taking abs after uniform. The problem was it wasn't setting the atol parameter in assert_allclose, so it was defaulting to 0. I've fixed this and also set the uniform so it will never output 0 which may cause log to fail.

The functions are already covered by the test cases, the problem was that one (or more) of the include files in topi.cc declared `using namespace topi::detail` so it didn't fail when including the other files.

I have encountered a problem that is essentially blocking OpenGL codegen.

If we write this program:

```python
m = 2
n = 2
p = 2
A = tvm.placeholder((m, n, p), name='A', dtype="int32")
B = tvm.compute((m, n, p), lambda *i: A[i], name="B")

s = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
print(tvm.lower(s, [A, B], simple_mode=True))
s[B].opengl()
...
```

This program lowers to:

```
B[(((((threadIdx.x/4)*2) + ((threadIdx.x/2) % 2))*2) + (threadIdx.x % 2))] = A[(((((threadIdx.x/4)*2) + ((threadIdx.x/2) % 2))*2) + (threadIdx.x % 2))]
```

However, it actually should be simplified to:

```
B[threadIdx.x] = A[threadIdx.x]
```

It turns out that the following 2 programs can be properly simplified:

```python
# 2D tensor
m = 2
n = 2
A = tvm.placeholder((m, n), name='A', dtype="int32")
B = tvm.compute((m, n), lambda *i: A[i], name="B")

s = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
print(tvm.lower(s, [A, B], simple_mode=True))
s[B].opengl()
...
```

```python
# 3D tensor but with variable shape
m = tvm.var("m")
n = tvm.var("n")
p = tvm.var("p")
A = tvm.placeholder((m, n, p), name='A', dtype="int32")
B = tvm.compute((m, n, p), lambda *i: A[i], name="B")

s = tvm.create_schedule(B.op)
print(tvm.lower(s, [A, B], simple_mode=True))
s[B].opengl()
...
```

I figured out that the reason is that `StorageFlatten` is not smart enough to simplify the index expression.

I think currently I can work around this by adding some kind of attribute which says "threadIdx.x maps to the corresponding element in the output tensor", and then directly putting `B[threadIdx.x]` in `StorageFlatten`.
We should already handle similar logics， maybe try to change the order you fuse multiple axis cc @sxjscience
Yes, refer to the PR here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/267. We should be able to further improve the strategy if you have some ides.
My guess is that you can already get what you want by using a different way to fuse all axis(we can do it either from first to last, or from last to first) @phisiart

The current rule does not seem to be correct for elem_offset calculation for different data types, because the index calculation need to be translated among different types(they are in unit of access element type)
cc @libing4752  who looked at this issue before
this should have already been supported after #868

If we have 
```c++
int32 a[10];
int64 b[10];

b[i] = ...

```
after merging b after a, it should become (note cast and index is semantics of access ptr)
```c++
int32 a_b_combo[10 + 20];

(cast<int64*>(a_b_combo))[5 + i] = ...
```
cc @merrymercy
should we unify all types or just unify types for space reusing vars?
didn't get what you mean, maybe provide an example proposal? The current definition of access_ptr is fine as long as we do it right and respect its definition

@tqchen 
(cast<int64*>(a_b_combo))[5 + i] = ...
How does tvm generate stmt like this? 
seems Cast::make only can cast to a type instead of pointer type
OK, @merrymercy thanks a lot
Use a_b_combo.access_ptr(ptr_type="int64")? But for my understanding, it should generate "cast<int64>" not "cast<int64*>".
that's pyton's api. what i need to do is make that ir generate in ir mutate, in which i don't know how to do that
please fix the lint error http://mode-gpu.cs.washington.edu:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/dmlc%2Ftvm/detail/PR-878/1/pipeline

I tried fusing from the other direction (last to first), but it's still not getting simplified fully.

This time I got `B[((((threadIdx.x/4)*2)*2) + (threadIdx.x % 4))] = A[((((threadIdx.x/4)*2)*2) + (threadIdx.x % 4))]`.

In `src/lang/buffer.cc`, when simplifying the index expression, it is searching for a pattern like `(e / m) * m + e % m`, and change that to `e`.

When I fuse from first to last, I get `((x / 4) * 2 + (x / 2) % 2) * 2 + x % 2`, but when I fuse from last to first, I get `x / 4 * 2 * 2 + x % 4`. Neither of the expressions has the desired form for simplification.

I think that rather than improving and depending on expression simplification (which we can guarantee to be sound but not necessarily complete, especially when we might have vars and imms mixed together it would be even more complex), we should do something similar to what Halide does: when we know we are in a shader, we don't create a `Store` stmt but a special `Call::image_store` stmt (which will later be transformed to `Call::glsl_texture_store` [see here](https://github.com/halide/Halide/blob/master/src/StorageFlattening.cpp#L247).
@phisiart That is a possible solution that we can adopt

Now it works for cuda, opencl on mali T860 and GTX 1050 Ti. All the results are reasonable.

Usage examples
```
python3 -m tvm.exec.measure_peak --target cuda --rpc-host 0.0.0.0 --rpc-port 9090
python3 -m tvm.exec.measure_peak --target opencl --target-host "llvm -target=aarch64-linux-gnu" \
       --rpc-host 10.42.0.96 --rpc-port 9090
```

I am not sure what is happening on your side, but it didn't happen my my version of metal, see also https://developer.apple.com/metal/Metal-Shading-Language-Specification.pdf Maybe you need to upgrade your metal support?

I take a look at the code. The additional argument is supposed to indicate the position of the new axis. But I don't know how to define the arg.
1. s.rfactor(tensorA, reduce_axis, pos). It is simple, but I think you would not prefer this way.
2. s.rfactor(tensorA, reduce_axis, factor_axis). The factor_axis is a list of axis refer to the generated factor_tensor, including the new axis. But it would suggest a reorder of axes, which could not be support.

Could you give me a simple example the explain how to design the api ? Then I could start to fix this.
Update: the first set of ops are done. Now `nnvm/tutorials/define_and_compile_model.py`'s resnet runs successfully in local OpenGL.

I think it is fine making factor_axis as int(instead of the final generated axis). 

We can always refer to numpy for API design, for example  https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.expand_dims.html

Or I should not even do this in the first place.
The code seems to be fine, the error said that union is not supported by the compiler. Maybe you can upgrade your metal support as seems latest version of metal do support union types

for this case:
```
def test_alloc_seq_type():
    ib = tvm.ir_builder.create()
    n = tvm.var("n")
    with ib.for_range(0, n, name="i") as i:
        with ib.for_range(0, 10, name="j") as j:
            A = ib.allocate("float32", 200, name="A", scope="local.L0A")
            A1 = ib.allocate("float32", 200, name="A1", scope="local.L0A")
            A[j] = 1.2
            A1[j] = 1.3
            A2 = ib.allocate("float32", 200, name="A2", scope="local.L0A")
            A2[j] = 1.4
            B = ib.allocate("int16", 200, name="B", scope="local.L0A")
            B[j] = tvm.const(1, "int16")
            C = ib.allocate("int16", 200, name="C", scope="local.L0A")
            C[j] = tvm.const(1, "int16")
            D = ib.allocate("int16", 200, name="D", scope="local.L0A")
            D[j] = C[j] + B[j]
            E = ib.allocate("float32", 200, name="E", scope="local.L0A")
            E[j] = A[j] + A1[j]

    body = ib.get()
    body = tvm.ir_pass.StorageRewrite(body)
```
we can get ir like with patch 
```
// attr [A] storage_scope = "local.L0A"
allocate A[float32 * 700]
for (i, 0, n) {
  for (j, 0, 10) {
    A[j] = 1.200000f
    A[(200 + j)] = 1.300000f #view A as float32
    A[(400 + j)] = 1.400000f
    A[(400 + j)] = (int16)1 #view A as int16, 400 should be 800?
    A[(1200 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[(1200 + j)] = (A[(1200 + j)] + A[(400 + j)])
    A[(200 + j)] = (A[j] + A[(200 + j)])
  }
}
```
without it
```
// attr [A] storage_scope = "local.L0A"
allocate A[float32 * 800]
for (i, 0, n) {
  for (j, 0, 10) {
    A[j] = 1.200000f
    A[(200 + j)] = 1.300000f
    A[(400 + j)] = 1.400000f
    A[(1200 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[(1400 + j)] = (int16)1
    A[(1200 + j)] = (A[(1400 + j)] + A[(1200 + j)])
    A[(200 + j)] = (A[j] + A[(200 + j)])
  }
}
```
